item.title: Cada vez más adolescentes toman antidepresivos. Podrían alterar su vida sexual por años
item.description: Los estudios sobre adultos que toman ISRS muestran que estos medicamentos reducen la libido. ¿Por qué no se analiza lo que esto podría significar para los chicos?
item.dc:creator: Daniel Bergner

media:content.media:credit: Photo illustration by The New York Times

item.title: George Clooney, Adam Sandler y Noah Baumbach hablan de la fama y de ‘Jay Kelly’
item.description: Las estrellas y el director recuerdan sus días intentando abrirse camino en la industria y cómo el fracaso formaba parte de la ecuación.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Chantal Anderson

media:content.media:credit: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Noah Baumbach with Sandler and Clooney in Beverly Hills.

item.title: Listening to a Book Counts as Reading
item.description: We need to let go of our legacy print snobbery.
item.dc:creator: Brian Bannon

media:content.media:credit: Alexander Coggin for The New York Times

item.title: In Russian-Occupied Mariupol, Everything Ukrainian Must Go
item.description: Russia is remaking Mariupol, which was devastated by a brutal siege in 2022. Ukrainians seeking to move back are finding it hard to recognize the city, or to reclaim their property.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar, Milana Mazaeva and Anna Lukinova

media:content.media:description: A newly built residential building in Mariupol, in August 2023. The city has undergone drastic changes since the Russian military took the city in 2022.

item.title: Quote of the Day: How Learning a Dying Craft Helped One Man Fix His Life
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 23, 2025.

item.title: EE. UU. presiona a un Zelenski ya asediado
item.description: Las opciones del presidente ucraniano se reducen al enfrentarse a una propuesta de 28 puntos elaborada por enviados estadounidenses y rusos.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Paul Sonne

media:content.media:description: La 148.ª Brigada de Artillería preparándose para disparar contra objetivos rusos en la región de Zaporizhzhia, en el este de Ucrania, en octubre.

item.title: Corrections: Nov. 23, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 23, 2025.

item.title: A Swath of Bank Customer Data Was Hacked. The F.B.I. Is Investigating.
item.description: SitusAMC, a technology vendor for real estate lenders, holds sensitive personal information on the clients of hundreds of its banking customers, including JPMorgan Chase.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland, Stacy Cowley and Devlin Barrett

media:content.media:description: JPMorgan Chase was among the banks notified by SitusAMC that its client data may have been breached.

item.title: Georgia Voters Stand by Marjorie Taylor Greene After She Stood Up to Trump
item.description: Ms. Greene’s resignation blindsided her conservative Georgia district, which had stuck by her through ups and downs, including her split with the president.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Sean Keenan

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene during a news conference about the Epstein Files Transparency Act in September.

item.title: Tatiana Schlossberg, John F. Kennedy’s Granddaughter, Reveals Terminal Cancer Diagnosis
item.description: Tatiana Schlossberg, a daughter of Caroline Kennedy, revealed a terminal cancer diagnosis in an essay published on the anniversary of her grandfather’s assassination.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell

media:content.media:description: Tatiana Schlossberg in 2023 during an event at the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum in Boston.

item.title: Second in Command
item.description: Trenton Charlson takes charge of your Sunday with an imposing puzzle.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Lovinger

media:content.media:credit: General Photographic Agency/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Wax models of three executed murderers on display in the Chamber of Horrors attraction at Madame Tussauds in London, circa 1935.

item.title: Texas Men Plotted Coup of Haitian Island to Enslave Women and Children, U.S. Says
item.description: The men, who planned to recruit homeless people for the invasion, took Haitian Creole classes and one enrolled in the U.S. Air Force to prepare for an attack by sailboat, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

media:content.media:description: The island of Gonave as seen from Port-au-Prince, Haiti. Two Texas men were indicted in a murder and kidnapping plot that called for staging a coup of the island, federal prosecutors said.

item.title: Before Berlin’s Cowboys Are Booted Off Their Land, One Final Hoedown
item.description: The town looks straight out of the Wild West, with saloons, sheriffs and cowboy hats galore, but in this endangered patch of the American frontier, everyone is speaking German.

media:content.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The expected demise and demolition of Old Texas Town comes as both the club members, and a peculiar German love for the American West, are growing old.

item.title: For Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Rough Education in MAGA Politics
item.description: The Georgia congresswoman strove to be both the ultimate Trump warrior and to be taken seriously. She wound up in political exile.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

media:content.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene in February 2021, the day after the Democratic-majority House voted to remove her from her committee assignments.

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Exit Deals a Blow to Republicans’ Majority in Congress
item.description: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene’s sudden resignation underscored the fragility of the G.O.P. majority, and exposed deep discontent on the right going into the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In the wake of Marjorie Taylor Greene’s announcement, other Republicans chimed in to echo her dissatisfaction with what their party has accomplished.

item.title: ‘Wicked: For Good’ Takes Flight at Box Office, Expected to Make Over $150 Million
item.description: The movie is expected to take in about $151.5 million from Friday through Sunday, earning 35 percent more than the first installment last year.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling

media:content.media:description: Cast members at the premiere of “Wicked: For Good” in New York on Monday. Its opening weekend was the second biggest of the year.

item.title: Dorothy Vogel, Librarian With a Vast Art Collection, Dies at 90
item.description: On modest civil servants’ salaries, she and her husband amassed a trove of some 4,000 works by art-world luminaries, storing them in their one-bedroom Manhattan apartment.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

media:content.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Dorothy Vogel with her husband, Herbert, in a New York gallery in 1992. Their Manhattan rent-controlled apartment functioned as a fine-art storage locker as well as an exhibition space for thousands of works by contemporary artists.

item.title: A.I. Toy Bear Speaks of Sex, Knives and Pills, Consumer Group Warns
item.description: The chatter left startled adults unsure whether they heard correctly. Testers warned that interactive toys like this one could allow children to stray into inappropriate exchanges.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker

media:content.media:description: A screen shot of the FoloToy website, advertising its A.I.-enabled stuffed bear, named Kumma.

item.title: Abortion Is Once Again Illegal in North Dakota
item.description: On Friday, a state Supreme Court ruling reinstated a near-total abortion ban, reversing a judge’s earlier decision.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao

media:content.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Red River Women’s Clinic, once the only abortion provider in North Dakota, was forced to move across state lines to Minnesota as a result of new state laws in 2022.

item.title: Lemurs in Madagascar Face an Unexpected Killer
item.description: Thousands of the endangered primates end up on the dinner plates of people in the upper rung of the country’s society who have money to spare.
item.dc:creator: Dina Fine Maron

media:content.media:description: A bamboo lemur (Hapalemur occidentalis) eating bamboo.

item.title: Security Lapse Allowed Protesters to Disrupt Performance, Met Opera Says
item.description: Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, said a security guard was absent from his post when two people climbed onstage at a performance of “Carmen.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

media:content.media:description: The Metropolitan Opera in 2024. A protest at a performance of “Carmen” on Friday night led to a scene of chaos and confusion.

item.title: Trump’s Proposed Ukraine ‘Deal’ Is a Disgrace
item.description: If Ukraine is forced to surrender to these terms by Thursday, Thanksgiving will no longer be an American holiday. It will become a Russian holiday.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman

item.title: John Green on the Cost of Internet Fame
item.description: The author John Green found an audience of millions making YouTube videos with his brother, Hank. As more people aspire to become influencers, he warns that internet fame may make it feel like everyone knows and loves you, “but in fact, no one knows you.”
item.dc:creator: The Interview

item.title: 20 Killed in Israeli Strikes as Israel and Hamas Trade Blame Over Truce
item.description: Violence has repeatedly flared up in the weeks since a cease-fire was reached, killing hundreds of Palestinians and at least three Israeli soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Saher Alghorra

media:content.media:description: Rescue workers extinguishing a fire after an Israeli airstrike in western Gaza City on Saturday.

item.title: Terry Martin Hekker, a Happy Housewife Scorned, Dies at 92
item.description: She wrote two popular memoirs: the first about the joys of married life, the second about her husband serving her divorce papers on their 40th anniversary.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

media:content.media:description: Terry Martin Hekker in an undated photo. “I’m one of the last of the dying breed of human females designated ‘Occupation: Housewife,’” she wrote in the late-1970s.

item.title: Solange Knowles, Librarian: Expanding a Saint Heron Passion Project
item.description: The Grammy winner, now a scholar in residence at U.S.C., is expanding a one-of-a-kind library featuring rare books by writers of color. (Just mind the due date.)
item.dc:creator: Gina Cherelus

item.title: In the House, Censures Proliferate, Reflecting a Poisonous Climate
item.description: Formal reprimands, once rare, dominated the chamber’s agenda this week, prompting lawmakers in both parties to call for changes to the way the House handles such actions.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The U.S. Capitol building in Washington, last month. Official House rebukes, once exceedingly rare and mostly a matter of consensus for the most egregious conduct or illegal acts by a sitting member of Congress, have become commonplace in recent years.

item.title: Jair Bolsonaro es arrestado en Brasil por temor a su fuga
item.description: La detención se produjo días antes de que se ordenara al expresidente el inicio de una condena de 27 años de prisión por planear un golpe de Estado fallido.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

media:content.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro durante su arresto domiciliario en Brasilia el viernes. El expresidente fue detenido a la mañana siguiente.

item.title: COP30 Climate Summit Ends With Dire Warnings and Scant Plans for Action
item.description: The final agreement, with no direct mention of the fossil fuels dangerously heating Earth, was a victory for countries like Saudi Arabia and Russia, diplomats said.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

media:content.media:description: The closing session of the COP30 climate negotiations in Belém, Brazil, on Saturday.

item.title: Trump Is Mired in a War of Attrition
item.description: It’s not a winning strategy.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie

media:content.media:description: A Union soldier holding up the torn flag of the 8th Pennsylvania Reserve Color Guard.

item.title: Numa Molina, el sacerdote jesuita que defiende a Nicolás Maduro en Venezuela
item.description: El padre Molina fue uno de los primeros partidarios del predecesor de Maduro, Hugo Chávez, y su apoyo al gobierno socialista del país ha llevado a sus detractores a etiquetarlo como el ‘cura comunista’.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez

media:content.media:description: La gente hacía fila para fotografiarse con el padre Numa Molina tras una misa en Marizapa, Venezuela.

item.title: This Washington Museum Sold Some of Its Art. But at What Cost?
item.description: The Phillips Collection sold three works and raised $13 million to buy contemporary art, but the decision has led to rancor within the 104-year-old institution.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin

media:content.media:credit: Jonathan Newton/The Washington Post via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The Phillips Collection in Washington, D.C., is housed in the former family home of its founder, Duncan Phillips.

item.title: Five-Ingredient, Fiery Sweet Potatoes Recipe
item.description: If you have sweet potatoes, coconut milk, Thai red curry paste, brown sugar and butter (and salt), you have everything you need for this five-star side.
item.dc:creator: Mia Leimkuhler

media:content.media:credit: Linda Xiao for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Spencer Richards.
media:content.media:description: Julia Moskin’s fiery sweet potatoes.

item.title: On Police Footage and ‘The Perfect Neighbor’
item.description: Wesley Morris, the host of “Cannonball” at The New York Times, sits down with Parul Sehgal, a critic at large for The Times, to talk about the Netflix documentary “The Perfect Neighbor” and its use of police body camera footage.
item.dc:creator: Cannonball With Wesley Morris

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Resignation Hints at Divisions in Trump’s Movement
item.description: As the president forced a onetime loyalist from Congress, her defiant departure signaled a coming debate over Republican identity in a post-Trump era.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein

media:content.media:description: Again and again, President Trump has wielded the power that comes with the loyalty of his party’s base and an enormous war chest that he can leverage against opponents.

item.title: U.S. and Ukrainian Officials to Meet Again on U.S. Peace Plan
item.description: In the Trump administration’s latest effort to pressure Ukraine into accepting a 28-point peace plan, officials from the two countries will hold talks in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky at the White House in Washington, earlier this year. Ukraine’s European allies have criticized the 28-point proposal because it was initially negotiated between the United States and Russia, without Ukrainian involvement.

item.title: En estas fiestas, haz una lista de no pendientes
item.description: ¿Realmente tu familia necesita una cena con 13 guarniciones?
item.dc:creator: Jancee Dunn

item.title: No-Bake Cranberry Cookie Butter Cheesecake Recipe
item.description: My no-bake cranberry-cookie butter cheesecake with a crushed speculoos crust is a showstopper (if I do say so myself).
item.dc:creator: Vaughn Vreeland

media:content.media:credit: Linda Xiao for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Send me photos of your gorgeous cheesecakes!

item.title: Jair Bolsonaro Arrested in Brazil Amid Fears He Might Flee to Avoid Prison
item.description: The arrest came days before the former president was expected to be ordered to begin a 27-year prison sentence for staging a failed coup.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

media:content.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro during his house arrest in Brasília on Friday. The former president was arrested the next morning.

item.title: Cannon and Other Artifacts Are Recovered From San José Shipwreck
item.description: Colombian scientists also retrieved three coins and a porcelain cup from the San José, which treasure hunters have come to call the Holy Grail of shipwrecks.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

media:content.media:description: A photograph released by the Colombian government shows President Gustavo Petro examining a cannon that was recovered from the wreckage of the San José, a Spanish galleon that sank in 1708.

item.title: Chicago Shootings Leave One Dead and 8 Teenagers Wounded
item.description: Seven people, ages 13 to 17 were shot at a downtown gathering by the Chicago Theatre. A second shooting left a man dead and another teenager in serious condition.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado and Jonathan Wolfe

media:content.media:credit: Tyler Pasciak Lariviere/Chicago Sun-Times, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Chicago police investigating the scene of a shooting outside the Chicago Theater on Friday.

item.title: Stream These 5 Movies and TV Shows Before They Leave Netflix in December
item.description: Departures for U.S. subscribers next month include several classic comedies of the big and small screen — and one particularly prescient one.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey

media:content.media:description: Terry Crews (second from left) and Luke Wilson (second from right) in “Idiocracy.”

item.title: The Rise of the ‘Just in Case’ M.R.I.
item.description: A growing batch of companies give customers access to whatever medical tests they want — no doctor’s orders required.
item.dc:creator: Brent Crane

item.title: Daily Mail Owner Agrees to Buy The Telegraph, Consolidating Right-Leaning Media in Britain
item.description: The deal would combine two of the country’s major newspaper groups, a move likely to attract antitrust scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced

media:content.media:credit: Richard A. Brooks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Copies of British newspaper The Telegraph.

item.title: Trump Faces a Lame-Duck Economy
item.description: There are no easy answers for the current economic discontent.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat

media:content.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Naila Ruechel for The New York Times; sourece photograph by Justin Lane/Getty Images

item.title: Don’t Miss This: Epstein Edition
item.description: The Epstein files are coming. But will Americans be able to fully trust them?
item.dc:creator: Lauren Dominguez Chan, Ingrid Holmquist and Kathleen Kingsbury

item.title: A Call to Purge Washington of Epstein’s Associates
item.description: The release of more Epstein files could take down many prominent men in Washington — both Republicans and Democrats. But for the columnist Lydia Polgreen, the purge is not a bad thing. “You need this renewal,” she says on this episode of “The Opinions.”

item.title: Piggy Gets Polite
item.description: Trump, remarkably, finds a new low.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd

item.title: Jeffrey Epstein’s Victims Speak Out
item.description: On Tuesday, victims of the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein gathered to bring attention to the House vote to release the Epstein files. On this episode of “The Opinions,” the contributing Opinion writer Molly Jong-Fast describes the connection these women felt with one another and with their Republican advocate Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene. “They’re not faking it,” Jong-Fast says. “They had a real camaraderie.”

item.title: Trump Says the Epstein Documents Will Hurt Democrats, Too. Maybe That’s a Good Thing.
item.description: “You need this renewal. You need new figures who are untouched, who were never part of these awful power games,” the columnist Lydia Polgreen argues.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Polgreen, Molly Jong-Fast and Derek Arthur

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; photograph by Patrick McMullan
